headline: Trump's Georgia Rally Sees 'Smallest Crowd' in State Since 2016: Reporters
author: Jason Lemon
sentences: The former president pressured the southern state's GOP leadersGovernor Brian Kemp, Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger and Lieutenant Governor Geoff Duncanto overturn President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory in the state, but they declined to assist in the effort.

This is the smallest crowd I've seen at a rally of his in Georgia since he won the 2016 electionsignificantly smaller than the crowd in Perry in September," Greg Bluestein, a political reporter at The Atlanta Journal-Constitution tweeted.

As the correspondent, Mike D. or "Mikenificent," interviewed people lining up to attend the rally, he commented live: "Alright, not as much energy from the crowd as I was hoping for, but we're happy that you're tuned in."

While the former president has regularly seen tens of thousands attend his events in the state, as well as other states across the country, journalists assessed that the crowd size was underwhelming this weekend.

Former President Donald Trump's Georgia rally on Saturday failed to draw the number of supporters he has been accustomed to in the southern state, according to multiple journalists covering the event.

pic.twitter.com/2NKLACFhQX

Fowler also reported that people in attendance began "streaming out" even as Trump was still speaking.

Stephen Fowler, a political reporter at Georgia Public Broadcasting, shared a similar assessment.
Instead he asserted that the incumbent governor is "focused on making sure [Democratic gubernatorial candidate] Stacey Abrams is never our governor or the next president."
Trump continues to baselessly claim that Georgia's 2020 election results were fraudulent, despite multiple audits and recounts reaffirming Biden's narrow victory there.
This is the smallest crowd I've seen at a rally of his in Georgia since he won the 2016 election -- significantly smaller than the crowd in Perry in September.
Trump held the event in support of several of Georgia's Republican primary candidates in Commerce, Georgia, which is about an hour drive northeast of Atlanta.
Way less than the Perry rally in 2021 (closer to 10k) and nowhere close to 2020's 20-30k+," the journalist wrote in a Twitter post, sharing photos as well.
"It's almost time for Trump to speak here in Georgia and there's probably no more than 5,000 people here, the smallest Trump rally I've ever covered here.
Despite supporting the former president, the Republican secretary of state has strongly pushed back against his allegations that the results were tainted.
The journalist's comment about "enthusiasm" seemed to be backed up by a correspondent for Right Side Broadcasting Network (RSBN) ahead of the event.

Even people sitting on bleachers flanking Trump have been streaming out.
This matches what I've seen at GOP events across the state: they don't hate Trump but think his picks against strong conservatives are way off.
In a statement emailed to Newsweek on Saturday evening, Kemp spokesperson Cody Hall did not address questions about Trump's attacks directly.
Kemp similarly declined to support Trump's efforts to overturn Georgia's election results, as did Duncandrawing the former president's ire.
"We had a massive crowd last night in Georgia, but as usual, the Fake News Media absolutely refuses to show it," the former president said.
He also shared photos from different times during the event, showing that the venue got emptier as the former president spoke.
Newsweek contacted local police to ask for their estimates of the crowd size, but did not immediately receive a response.
The former president has endorsed former GOP Senator David Perdue, who is running against Kemp in the May 24 primary.
Those controversial actions by Trump remain under investigation by Fulton County District Attorney Fani Willis.
Ahead of the event, Duncan, who is not seeking reelection, told ABC News that Trump is "out to settle a score."
Trump spokesperson Liz Harrington disputed the journalists' assessments in a Sunday morning email to Newsweek.
Abrams, who previously lost to Kemp in 2018, has repeatedly said that she aims to be president some day.
"If Brian Kemp is renominated, he will go down in flames at the ballot box," Trump told the crowd.
Those reviews were overseen by Raffensperger, who voted for Trump and donated to his campaign.
Trump supporters on social media described the crowd as "massive," "huge" and "fired up."
In a second email she added: "Official estimates are between 25,000 and 35,000 people."
The Republican official said "that's no way to keep conservative leadership in power."
During the event, Trump doubled-down on attacks against Georgia's Republican leaders.
Bluestein shared a video clip that also appeared to back up what Fowler reported.
"Folks are starting to file out," the journalist tweeted shortly after 9 p.m.
In the clip, rally attendees can be seen leaving as Trump is speaking.
